intro: Caraguata palustris, commonly known as the swamp caraguata, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Brazil. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, herbaceous stems and broad, heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in clusters during the warmer months. It thrives in wetland and marshy environments, adapting to saturated soil conditions. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
